reviewText:
POST RELEASE REVIEW
I have had a most pleasurable privilege and experience of being part of testing this game since Alpha 2 update. I can honestly say this the best game in the GC series. Over the past year it has been an honor to work with the developers looking for bugs and help make this game the best it can be. For the past year no other game captured my interest as much as Galactic Civilizations III has, I have enjoyed testing, breaking and playing the game and will continue to do so. I was a big Fan of GC2 and GC3 has not disappointed me at all.

Now here we are on release day just two hours from official release and I find myself sitting here like a kid under a Christmas tree waiting for Santa to come down the chimney with my presents.

Stardock is a company like no other. They delivered a fantastic 4x strategy game just like they promised they would. They listened to everyone and gave us everything they could with so much more to be added later.

I got this game last year as a Father's Day gift and it's truly been the gift that keeps on giving. Game of the year 2015

Thank you Brad. Paul and the entire GC3 team. WONDERFUL GAME!!!!!

reviewText:
Good game, really goes for your hours played record. Will feel familiar to anyone whos played either of the previous 2.
New players may find the game a little difficult to get into at the start as the game doesnt really tell you alot &
the tech tree is flippin huge!!!!! its worth sticking with & the designing of your own ships is still one of the best features in a game (you really can spend hours on this without trying, more games should do this)
I do think the single player game difficulty levels need to be tweeked a bit, the level between normal & challenging feels a little too wide - normal often being way too easy & challenging maybe a little too so with certain setups
Still one of the better space strategy series out there

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSome of you may recognize me and my name from my work on Elemental: War of Magic". If you do
date: then you'll know that I know what I'm talking about when it comes to Stardock games.\n\nGalactic Civilizations III is the successor to the wildly popular Galactic Civilizations II. If you are familiar with Gal Civ II then you should largely know what to expect this time around. There is a multitude of options and settings
recommended: performance tweaks and graphical settings. Everything you can think of from Gal Civ II is here and improved upon. Some of the options from the expansions of Gal Civ II are missing
hoursPlayed: but
voteText: if you know Stardock and how they do things then you know those options are coming in future expansions and DLC.\n\nBeing the first installment (base game) there are things that can be improved upon
helpfulPercent: again though if you know Stardock then you know these things are coming down the road. I wouldn't say they left things out on purpose
votesHelpful: but more so because they know they have to have content for future expansions. Have no fear that some of those options you may notice that are missing from Gal Civ II WILL eventually be in Gal Civ III as well. If you'd like proof of this look at the base game (no expansions) of Gal Civ II
votesTotal: then look at Gal Civ II Ultimate Edition and everything that was added in between. This is a pattern with Stardock and they will follow the same pattern here.\n\nThe Gal Civ series has been my favorite Space 4X strategy series since Masters of Orion 1&2. The only thing lacking in Gal Civ in my opinion is directly controllable battles
votesFunny: though you do still have many options when it comes to battles. What roles you design for your ships and how well you design them plays a huge part in battles
commentsCount: and the battles are epic and beautiful. Ground battles and invasions are a bit "bare bones" at the moment
column16: but I can promise you this will be expanded upon with further updates and expansions as well.\n\nModdability in Gal Civ III is Off The Charts!!! This time around basically the entire game is opened up for modding
column17: even more so than Gal Civ II
column18: and you don't need to be a master programmer to do it. New mods and content are being worked on as I type this and the future of Gal Civ III is as bright as the brightest star in the universe. There's nothing here not to like.\n\nIf you've ever been a fan of 4X strategy games or Space strategy games then the only thing you need to be asking yourself right now is "Why haven't I bought this yet?!?!". Don't miss out on this epic gem of a game. If you only buy 1 strategy 4X this year there's no question in what you should be doing right now. Buy it

reviewText: So i have to say when I first bought this game i will be honest that i felt a little let down but, with its interactive team and constant updates I can proudly say this game has become a lot of fun. I suggest doing the tutorial as there are things you need to learn and playing with the tech tree a lot. The camera for the space fights can get some fine tuning but overall they are enjoyable to watch. Combat itself is a huge numbers game with range, defense, and attack all playing a factor in your fight to dominate. Choices on your races ideals and influence will greatly determine how you interact with the ai diplomatically. Fight everyone or try to be the peaceful race or even something in between its up to you.

reviewText:
Galactic Civilizations 3 is the latest in a series of space 4X games by Stardock. With this game really what you see is what you get- it really is a highly evolved space based version of civilisation. If you like Civilisation chances are you will love this. That being said there are both positive and negative aspects to this title which sets it apart from its brother. During this review I plan to outline those elements to help you make up your mind on this product. Full Disclosure, I have been a very long term fan of Stardock and their business practises- I backed the game at the $100 “all dlc included” level and in doing so you could say I have a vested interest in seeing this game succeed. That said, I still feel like I should be able to help you make up your mind.
I have been following Galciv3 since it was first announced and released into early access. One of the first things someone may ask is; how much has changed since this game entered early access? Well the game has seen an entire UI, graphical and gameplay overhaul since the initial alpha stages. Generally the patches came out once ever few months and overhauled the entire game each time. I expect this to be a similar pace to what we will see when development of DLC , Expansions and Patches begins. Stardock is very transparent with their community and often lets users see content long before release during dev streams. To get a good idea of just how much has changed, try watching one of their oldest streams before watching one of their newer ones... it is night and day.
Things are changing sure, but how is the gameplay? Well, upon starting a new game players’ have the option of customising everything similar to Civilisation. They may tweak the universe to be as hostile or peaceful as they want, crowded or sparse. Players can even design their own civilisation by choosing traits, style and AI personality. Upon starting players are given a scout ship (exploration), a colony ship (settler) and a survey ship (dedicated goodie hut finder). From here the player strives towards one of multiple goals. All the usual suspects are there in the form of Conquest, Time, Research and Diplomacy- but the game also offers alternative victory options such as influence and ascension. The maps can be any size from small 5 min blastoffs to full multi day megamatches. However if you plan on playing on the highest map size (insane) you will really need a beefy PC. Often the slightly smaller sizes of Gigantic, Immese or Excessive are much more “playable”, but they have made recent strives which have allowed me to play Insane til victory comfortably.
So just how IS performance anyway? The first thing you need to know about GalCiv3 is that it REQUIRES a 64bit OS to play- if you do not have one you really should be barking up another tree. The game seems to use a large chunk of ram and I can imagine Ram speed being a much higher requirement then in most games. Unlike Civilisation games, GalCiv3 boasts pretty impressive multi-core management. Each AI player runs on a single core/thread until all your cores are doing something. After that deal out starts again. Turn speeds will eventually become an issue, but the release version seems much better than it was even a few days ago.
The game is not flawless in its current state. There are bugs and the occasional tooltip error but Stardock says that they plan on supporting GalCiv3 for many years. Currently the plan is to release a series of DLC and Expansion packs slowly over the next few years along with free and sizable patches. How well they actually go with this is yet to be determined but they were generally pretty good with that during the past two GalCiv games. My biggest issue with the game at this time is more the perceived loss of character in the random events. The pictures for these events are not yet as diverse and interesting as they seemed in previous games and I often found myself selecting choices based on stats and ideological desires instead of picking what I would actually do. Another thing which personally irks me is the lack of “Wonders”. Generally there are only a small number of ‘one per galaxy’ buildings which are placed at late places in the tech tree. While in a game of Civilisation the question is “is it worth aiming for this wonder which everyone else could be aiming for”, in Galciv3 it is more like ‘oh, I must be the first person to get this tech. better build the wonder. No need to rush though, likely they have specialised in a different tech tree.’
In a first for the series Multiplayer is also included- though it is normally always best to play with someone you actually know as games could last a long time. Unfortunately the “Play by Email” option which was once common for games such as this is not possible. Multiplayer has not tarnished the familiar features though, nor has it taken centre stage. The signature Ship Designer feature is still very much in play, as is a scripted story based campaign. You can still watch your space battles in a pretty impressive (but hands off) way and you still have a (disappointingly simple) invasion screen. There are no Planet Busters currently (eg Terror Star) but they are planned for a later Expansion pack (much like in previous titles). Overall the gameplay is fluid and polished- playing the game feels much better than playing GalCiv2 did.
Overall I would easily recommend this game, especially if you like the promise of future DLC and Expansion packs. The game is a complete, polished and next generation 4X game which presses all the right buttons for me. Galciv3 is like the Cities Skylines to the CitiesXL or Sim City... A game which is much better optimised at doing what it needs to do, capturing the essence of what people love about the genre without killing your computer. With that in mind I say bravo Stardock- and please bring on the expansions, DLC and Steam Workshop (which will be added in version 1.1).

reviewText: This game has a lot going for it.  BUT it is not finished.  Lots of bugs.  Big ship battles are not fun to watch.  Graphics get real choppy which eventually leads to a lock-up.  The game does try to recover but in the end, A WASTE OF TIME.  I want my $40 back.  I am using an Alien 17 laptop with i7 and windows 7.  This is a true game machine. GCII, WOW, LOL, plus lots of stand alone games run fine.  Also, you have to log-in to play.  Well my ranch in AZ does not have the net. So I can't play there or I have to HOTSPOT my iPhone, which brings up another nightmare.

reviewText:
Game is filled with bugs, to the point it's unplayable. All sorts of different issues that causes the game to crash to desktop, none of which in my experience are performance related either. Try to join MP and it crashes, try to perform certain actions within the game and it'll crash. With no real response from Stardock support.

Aside from the bugs it's not a deep game for a 4x, right now anyway. You'll see a lot of the same dialogue and events within your first game alone. AI behaves oddly as well, for example civilizations that are far weaker than you will demand that you make weekly payments to them.

The ship designer is very nice though and well done, basically a game within a game.

reviewText: I had originally reviewed this game as recommended. I liked the soundtrack, the gameplay, and the look.  The most recent patch has overhauled" (Read: dumbed down) economic management to the point that the game is just not worth playing at all. Managing the research
recommended: and wealth of my empire and striking a balance between the three was what I really liked-the war isn't bad or a chore by any means but it's really just not where I found the meat of the gameplay to be. Now that governing my planetary budget is forcibly automated there's nothing to DO. Even the vaunted (and very fun
hoursPlayed: I might add) player-created starships have gotten hit by this change-now that you can no longer put 100% of a planet's outcome into military production all the player-made ships are too expensive to produce in any kind of reasonable timeframe.\n\nTL;DR:the meat of the gameplay was almost entirely removed in a patch

reviewText:
Thre are definitly parts of this game I enjoy emensly but there are others that make this a struggle to play, particullarly the longer the game goes on.

My biggest complaint is the level of micormanagement that is NECCESSARY in order to play this game. There are several things in the games that *should* releive the level of micromanagement, but they don't work how you would like. There is a global production governence that allows you to drive your indistry, but having one item for your entire empire makes things difficult. if you are primarily working on research, newer planets suffer when they could be building up their infrastructure, and provide fulfilling help to the empire, but instead being on the global governence they will contribute a pitence of research and almost never build up their infristructure. prior to 1.4 each planet could have its own governence but this became a nightmare of micromanagement when you had a large number of planets. they created an interesing  in-between" that allows you to divirert things but in my opinion it is not enough to help balence things where they were before.

The game has the ability to rely on the provided ai to assist with some of the micomanagement
date: however the AI is horible. It builds things almost at random
recommended: and the ship designs are just as worse.\n\nLast complaint is the space stations. it takes roughly 35 constor modules to fully build up a space station. the AI will only create constructors with only one construcotor modules
hoursPlayed: but with some work ones with 10+ modules can be created but it requires you to specifically send them roughout the univers instead of using the "oh so conviennt" request constructor button
voteText: which only uses the base constuctor. So instead of creating 2 ships for a fully build base it requires the 35.\n\nThese are my biggest complaints. Overall though I enjoy the game as it is nice and relaxing. I just hate the 10 minutes I spend every turn directing my ships and orginizing my planets. If they can fix these things I will change my review but overall I give it an (7/10)."

reviewText: I like it, despite last AI upgrade but AI still long way to go, which need lot of improvement. Let see right now, I don't recommend it.

Great gameplay.  The gameplay is centered more around the overall interstellar play.  The battles are simulated so your focus is more about the governereal aspect.  I thought I would hate this but I actually kind of like it.\n\nCrashes way too much for my liking.

Why did you remove the planet production wheel?

Why is it not even an option anymore?

Why did you think it was a good idea to change such a large gameplay element when it's not in alpha (or even beta for that matter) anymore?

With it's removal you've just promoted improvement spam, made the game needlessly long and made it a requirement that planets manufacture and research constantly, otherwise it's wasting raw production.

And yes I know that currently I am talking about an update that is in beta (not that it matters, major gameplay changes shouldn't be done in beta), but the developers have been talking about removing the wheel for a while. With the next mandatory update the planet production wheel will be gone.

This game has been ruined.

Edit:

The main game has been updated, the planet production wheel has been officially removed.

Edit [5/11/15]:

Despite the dev being arsey about it, the wheel is back:

1. Opt into the 1.41 Beta.
2. Run the game once.
3. In 'prefs.ini' set 'UseColonyProductionWheel' to 1.

As long as the wheel stays, my review stays positive.

I've been playing stardock Cal Civ games since the first incarnation of the series. Cal Civ 3 is the best of all three versions.

This game can only improve when the devs release the planed DLC's and upgrades.

I'm looking forward to the improvements coming in Upgrade 1.40

After they removed the wheel, the community asked to have it reinstalled, Stardock listened and brought it back. This game  =10 of 10

I regret buying this game. Why?
(Firstly, not one image in the videos is from actual game footage. Do not be deceived. This game relies on marketing to sell it. If you knew what I knew, you would not buy this game as it is broken in terms of functioning code and game design).

Ok, some points about my game experience:
(you can check every point in the game and they are all factual events. My opinion is not fact but it reflects my observence of these facts in the game)

1 - Crashes every 15-30 minutes on insane mode due to memory leaks. I know it's memory leaks because there are arrays being created but not deleted or reused. Too much data is being accumulated somewhere and it results in the game becoming increasingly slower and slower and finally crashing and instantly going to desktop and closes the game.

You will have a new appreciation for saving your progress between autosaves when you have long periods of time per turn before the next auto-save. Especially if you just spent 20 minutes cleaning out obsolete units to try and help the game become faster.
----------
2 - The space battles look ok at first but after a while you'll notice that it looks like all the spaceships are controlled by drunk drivers who love nothing better than to fly around like a dead goldfish in a whirlpool. This happens as they get closer and the maker seems to have a bad sense of what looks acceptable.
----------
3 - Sound often crashes. To overcome this flaw in coding: the music must be turned off and then back on - don't ask me why but it fixes the sound error. Sometimes the game will become unresponsive but not crash and return to windows. When you can no longer interact with anything, just save your current game in a new slot and re-load your game.
----------
4 - Computer AI cheats. I have it's bases totally surrounded and it magically creates armies and bases out of nothing in the middle of nowhere. Then the AI will tell me it surrenders and yet I still have to kill it anyway. Don't know if this is a bug or the game designer has a twisted idea of the word 'surrender'. Seriously, cheating is a last ditch effort for programmers who cannot make adaptive AI.
----------
5 - the game should be fun but I found it more tedious than my previous job doing data entry of government records OR data entry for Toyota.
Why would I say this? There are few shortcuts to do anything in the game. You cannot mass delete, mass rally to a location, or even mass select other than stacking and making a fleet. There are no checkboxes or CTRL+Select to make selective deletion possible.

You have to do many things individually and honestly this game felt more like a horrible job except that I'm the one paying to do it.... The hotkeys mentioned online do not work in most cases. Y" works for yes
date: the working hotkeys are visible in tooltips but the online suggestions mostly do not work.\n----------\n6 - Just when you thought you were moving a slider to look at ships in a list
recommended: the tooltip blocks most of the list so you cannot even see what you are looking at.\n----------\n7 - the icons on the minimap are single pixels. Yes
hoursPlayed: you heard correctly
voteText: single pixels!!! Get ready for purple dot units on a purple background for it's team color. THe minimap is so bad I wanted to vomit
helpfulPercent: eat my vomit
votesHelpful: poop it out
votesTotal:
eat it again and vomit it again. It will provide hours of frustration as you squint to see wtf you are looking at. Also ship icons in groupings are impossible to recognize because they are just reduced scale images of large pictures. This results in "WTF is that?" moments and you have to then open up another menu to see what is what.
And I'm using a 24" screen 1900x1200 and the minimap is still terrible. Same color for ships on same color for your area of control....so bad....high school art class FTW...
----------
8 - The production and rally points are so messy that you'll find half your army hidden in buildings that you never intended them to be in.
----------
9 - I make games for a living and so that's partly why I'm so critical. However the game does have it's promising moments but most likely you'll be forcing yourself to play because you paid 40~70 dollars depending on what country you live in. I paid 70 :(
----------
10 - The game just isn't fun at all - that's my final opinion after I completed an 'insane size map' that took me 20 hours+ (probably another 2 hours if I include the lost time due to crashes).
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:
----------
Strategy:
The only strategy really is to look at what weapons your enemy's ships have
votesFunny: what armor they have
commentsCount: and then choose the best rock
column16: paper
column17: scissor effect to win fights. The technology you choose should support how you want to play. Influence to steal bases
column18: Friendly to win an alliance win
column19:
military to win fights and research to help you get an edge in whatever style you choose. Research alone will not win the game unless you choose that goal.
----------
Creativity:
If you want to be creative in this game
column20: you'll be very sad. The game has little opportunity for creativity and any startrek / starwars fetishes you have will be crushed when you see the ships floating like dead goldfish in a whirlpool. Yes
column21:
you can make spaceships with existing parts however the spaceships update so much and the game is so repetitive AND the battle scenes are so horrible that your art will be spat on by the current game design.
----------
Reward System:
The main rule is that the inefficient player will lose to the AI. So your first few games will be hard but once you have those "ah~~~I see " moments where you realise how to beat the AI
column22:
you'll finish it easily but it will just take lots of time.
Lack of patience is punished in this game.
----------
User Interface:
Patience is also punished because this game makes you a full time data entry person thanks to a useless user interface (UI) which only caters for short games where the structure and unit count is smaller. When you have like 400 of these
column23:
the game's UI fails and just shows a blank screen beyond about 200 units in the list. Really helpful when the spaceship you want is at the bottom of the list and the filters don't move it to the top.
----------
Price and Music:
Sorry to be critical but that's the way I am. I paid $70 for the game and I expected a $70 game but this seems more like a fancy prototype / alpha game. I wouldn't call it a beta because it was so buggy I really imagine the programmer to be inexperienced and not an eye for detail or design principles. Art is average but I'm very critical. Oh
column24: and Music is AWFUL...thank goodness for 3rd party music players. Really
column25:
really depressing music with no passion in it.
----------
Closing Thoughts:
Once again
column26:
sorry for being so critical but I earned that right when I paid $70 for a game that would have been fair if it was sold for $20~25

Now when I read the following quote:

"You must be running 64-bit Windows 7 or later to play Galactic Civilizations III. This requirement allows us to create the largest
column27: most advanced
column28:
strategy game possible."

- I believe this translates into:

"You need 64-bit because my coding is so bad that a 32 bit OS will fail very quickly because I can't clean arrays or debug my game. In other words
column29:
I'll break through my lack of coding skill by using your 64 OS to extend the life of my memory leaks."
----------
Lesson Learned:
I learned what kind of game design is less effective. This in turn helped me become a better game programmer. I'd avoid this game like the plague until the price comes down. Too late for me

reviewText:
Review as of v1.4:

I am a big fan of Galciv 2 and this game hits that Galciv feeling. I have no hesitation in recommending this game to 4x players. The game is really good, no question.

The devs have made a lot of progress since release; and 1.4 is a big improvement for the ai - for me most notably is that the ai won't spam starbases everywhere anymore.

My fav things:
- tech tree is so much better than galciv2
- nebulae and other stellar background (like black holes)
- strategic resources
- ship designer - it is insanely good
- building on planets is beautiful, smooth and satisfying (especially the adjacency mechanic - making this nicely strategic)

Issues:
- still buggy in places (but have never had a full on crash). Two bugs for me are that the ai spams messages which are clearly not relevant; and some information doesn't refresh straight away creating some genuine confusion as to what is happening.
- feature light-ish (this is only a comment in relation to galciv 2, it still has a great many features). I'm sure expansions will correct this and go beyond galciv 2; as it stands in no way is galciv 3 an incomplete game.
- small payable dlc ... why are these things not in base game kinda thing

Summary:
Gameplay is unquestionably fun, the world is immersive, the sound design is great and the ai is a challenge. This is a good 4x game and I look forward to further patches, development and of course the three planned expansions.

Go buy.

EDIT: forgot to say how awesome the multiplayer is, smooth and crisp. The game is also 64 bit which is a massive step up from galciv 2 creating what I can only describe as a brilliant play experience with no lag experienced yet.

I've been playing stardock Cal Civ games since the first incarnation of the series. Cal Civ 3 is the best of all three versions.

This game can only improve when the devs release the planed DLC's and upgrades.

I'm looking forward to the improvements coming in Upgrade 1.40

If you were a fan of Galactic Civlizations II, you will love Galactic Civilizations III.

It seems to have everything the other game had, with all the annoying bits taken out.
Starbase management no longer feels like a chore and the alien creator is much better, allowing you to create your own races of aliens and give guidelines for their personalities.

The strong RPG element of the game is still there, with a very complex system of diplomacy. The computer opponents don't simply try to defeat you and each other; they can be assigned general personalities. The many paths to victory also allows the player much flexibility in style.

Also, I give credit to Stardock for always abiding by strong standards and providing beautiful finished products. The battle simulator is extremely fun to watch, especially with large fleets. Play is intuitive, but complex.

In short, I found it to be a beautiful, fun product that no fan of the genre will want to be without.
ground combat is poor, needs to be more like MOO3. Everything else is great.

Not without it's flaws, GalCiv3 is a an excellent 4X game that provides the depth and interest expected in such a title.  Stardock isn't done getting things right but it's definitely a playable, solid game that brings depth, choice, and fun to the genre.  It was worth it at full price but if you can get it at a discount, you are ahead of the power curve with this game.

Yeah I like the game and it's worth getting if you like this sort of genre. There are a few problems I've found personally: for a start it's sometimes dificult to see which planets are mine, making them stand out more on the map would fix it. Secondly an enemy can win, which just happened to me, and I have no idea how. It's also possible to buy ships from an ally in exchange for technology, then use their own ships to invade them. :) You can also bankrupt an enemy, as I did, by buying loads of ships from allies then gift them to an enemy, the upkeep then destroys their econimy XD.\n\nPersonally I focus on food, growth and science, I also focus on one thing at a time normally... the mechanics are more or less fine, it's really just the interface which I dislike because like I said finding things like my ships, planets and star bases can be tricky.

Early Access Review\n\nGalCiv3 is a solid entry into the franchise. It has the elements you expect it to have -- combat, exploration, resource building and planet development, ship building, researching, diplomacy, etc. It's still got some work to be done but the development has been aggressive. I recommend it to anyone who enjoys 4X games, particularly space 4X games.

This game is great.

With this game Stardock has realised a solid platform in the 4x genre which offers the opportunity to futher add content to make this universe even more alive, improve the AI to offer more challenges and allow modding for extra content and hours and hours of real gaming pleasure.

Why?

Mainly because of the grand scale of this game. You can play in immense galaxies where it will take hours to make first contact, or you can easily create a death match style arena where everyone grabs you by the throat at once.

Even this beta version is already incredibly stable and vibrant. And I'm sure that tons of great additions can be expected over the course of time both user made and from the team.

If you are looking for a real competitor and succesor to your childhood Master of Orion 2 experience this is the place to start!

I've been playing Galactic Civilizations from the start of the series.  Fans of the earlier titles are likely to enjoy this iteration.  Most of the core ideas are well-implemented, and the look of the game is appropriately updated.  Particular highlights include a more diverse body of random events (even before obtaining the Mega Events DLC), an ideological system, race-specific tech trees, and an incredibly nuanced ship designer.  Of course, there is robust support for custom-designed content, which should proliferate as the playerbase grows.

For people unfamiliar with the series, Galactic Civilizations is about competitive empire-building.  In the standard game, a player begins with a spacefaring race still limited to its homeworld.  Simultaneously managing exploration, settlement, economic development, technological growth, and security concerns; the aim is to colonize distant worlds and thrive.  Victory conditions often include peaceful options like diplomacy or even transcending physical existence itself, though violent conquest is also on the list.  Managing large happy colonies provides the resources to attempt the loftiest goals.

Having played many games in this 4X genre, I feel Galactic Civilizations III strikes a nice balance between accessibility and complexity.  It is possible to control every detail right down to the placement of decorative fins on warships, but delegating to the AI to focus on high-level questions and strategic command is also a viable approach.  I don't yet have enough experience to have a strong opinion about the AI, but I find the normal difficulty setting suitable for learning the ropes.  Ideology is a particular treat, giving significant consequence to the morality of crucial choices.  For players willing to put in the time a serious strategy game demands, Galactic Civilizations III should provide many hours of pleasant satisfaction.

Galactic Civilizations III is a beautiful and well made 4x space empire managment game.  Having played MOO1, MOO2, Gal Civs 1,2 and now number 3, this is by far the most engaging and challenging game yet.
________________________________________________________________
Pros:
Very nice graphics all around.  Planets now show city lights on the dark side and the background is just beautiful.  Ships also really pop out.  Huge fleet battles looks really good!
The Ship Designer is top notch as always.  Plenty of options to make almost anything you can imagin.
A lot of nice fixes to diplomacy. Every race no longer DoW for no reason... except the Drengin but that's    expected.
The absolute huge size of the galaxy makes for some epic empire vs empire wars.  I only play on Insane size!
Civilization customization is well done and there are so many options to make the civilization of your dreams.
Steam Workshop support.  Makes up for the lack of starting civs by using the faction mods and can add some awesome looking ships to your game.  Lots of great work done by the community.
Continuing the story/campiegn from previous Gal Civs.  (That opening cutscene is just AWESOME!)

____________________________________________________________

Cons:

(As of this review) No planetary invasion cutscenes or otherwise some neat way of seeing your troops conquer the planet.  It all happens in the background instantly and is very anti-climatic.  This is something that was in previous Gal Civs but not in this one and it is a little bit of a let down.  I hold out hope that Stardock will add it in either by patch or DLC.

Needs some better management/organization options for fleets.  Whenever you add a ship to a fleet it changes the fleets name to some random number with your factions name.  For me the naming of fleets is important so I can at a glance of the list tell where certain fleets are without cycling though all of them. This can get annoying when upgrading ships you will need to change the fleet name each time you add the ship back into fleet.  When I have 50+ Fleets of various sizes and purposes running around, trying to remember which ones I named what can get frustrating.

Though civilizations will not DoW as much I still have the unbelieveable occurence of some civs (Drengin mostly) DoW even if they are not even remotly in range of my empire to fight/invade.  So it is a war in name only.  The AI bu now should be able to take into account the distance of it's empire to the one it wants to DoW.  When you make another Civ know you want to destroy them they tend to prepare for you and this kind of removes the possablility of being attacked by suprise (ex: Peral Harbor style)

AI Behavior in general:  The AI can behave in some strange ways and seems to lack proper skills to manage their own planets.  I tend to find their planets near rebellion or under developed.  I then find it strange to see with such poor managment how they can afford fleets of such epic size.  In fact I would say AI behavior is the biggest flaw in this game.
_________________________________________________________

Conclusion:  Depsite the cons, which are in my opinion really kinda minor when it comes to the rest of this game,  Galactic Civilizations III is one of the very top 4x strategy games on the market at this very moment.  Very engaging and beautiful, I tip my hat to you Stardock... well done.  I look forward to see what else you bring to this game and series.

I do recommend the game for those that played 1 and 2 or any of the Civilzation style games and liked them.  I did find some of the extreme times on research a bit tedious and I did find the income remains a bit too slow to develop.  I don't want to spend forever on the larger galaxies and that IS what it ends up feeling like when you make the research trees and income take that long while making the game start out at ridiculous sublight technology levels.  Too slow to develop and way too economically pinched to remain fun for any but the most devoted.  If you choose to cater to the extremists in this regard you will lose too many of the casuals.  I love this genre and I loved so much about this game other than the slow research trees and restrictively slow economic growth.  That being said my son, brother and best friend all played it once and I think the reiterated quote was It's no Masters of Orion"  although they did admit to my defense of the wonderful new ideas
date: expansive ship design and beautiful graphics.  You lost every one of them with one or both of my stated issues.  Myself
recommended: I like it albeit with the caveat of those issues."

reviewText:
Thre are definitly parts of this game I enjoy emensly but there are others that make this a struggle to play, particullarly the longer the game goes on.

My biggest complaint is the level of micormanagement that is NECCESSARY in order to play this game. There are several things in the games that *should* releive the level of micromanagement, but they don't work how you would like. There is a global production governence that allows you to drive your indistry, but having one item for your entire empire makes things difficult. if you are primarily working on research, newer planets suffer when they could be building up their infrastructure, and provide fulfilling help to the empire, but instead being on the global governence they will contribute a pitence of research and almost never build up their infristructure. prior to 1.4 each planet could have its own governence but this became a nightmare of micromanagement when you had a large number of planets. they created an interesing  in-between" that allows you to divirert things but in my opinion it is not enough to help balence things where they were before.

The game has the ability to rely on the provided ai to assist with some of the micomanagement
date: however the AI is horible. It builds things almost at random
recommended: and the ship designs are just as worse.\n\nLast complaint is the space stations. it takes roughly 35 constor modules to fully build up a space station. the AI will only create constructors with only one construcotor modules
hoursPlayed: but with some work ones with 10+ modules can be created but it requires you to specifically send them roughout the univers instead of using the "oh so conviennt" request constructor button
voteText: which only uses the base constuctor. So instead of creating 2 ships for a fully build base it requires the 35.\n\nThese are my biggest complaints. Overall though I enjoy the game as it is nice and relaxing. I just hate the 10 minutes I spend every turn directing my ships and orginizing my planets. If they can fix these things I will change my review but overall I give it an (7/10)."

This game does quite a bit right, the visuals and general interface feel better than previous versions, however in some respects it is currently an inferior product (as of version 1.10)\n\nIt attempts to simplify some systems, and expand others, but some minor problems with the new systems (shipyards, new starbase systems) change what was once a frustrating if effective macro/micro experience with a growing empire into a very tedious experience.  most of the problems with the game as-is come down to problems with the interface lacking information or more advanced controls, and while I admire the dedication to not using any automation systems in the game, at some point due to the scale, tweakable and powerful automation tools are virtually required, and honestly I find them quite satisfying.  The game will likely improve dramatically with subsequent patches and expansion.

Early on I have found cultural influence building and selecting cultural ideals that you can when they pop-up might be a bit OP as you can take over worlds without firing a shot.  Later on in the game though once everyone catches up with the military, this of course could hurt you unless you know how to diplomat your way into getting others to fight for you ;)  How you go about your civilization though is up to you, victory or fail!

A turn-based strategy game on a galactic scale. The short of it is, Galactic Civilizations 2 with a more simple and smooth feeling tech tree (or tech trees as the case is) which keeps the same capacity for user-created vessels and races.

Pros:
-Galactic Scale turn based strategy
-Customization to a reasonable extent without any need for modding
-Variable degrees of AI difficulty
-Honestly the graphics are quite lovely zoomed in, even if you'll usually have to zoom out to see things overall.

Cons:
-Game can feel 'slow', even for a turn-based strategy
-Tech trees can still be tedious to work through
-Random planet generation often likes to place tiles and upgrades in nonsensical places (Even homeworlds are random)
-Units turn pretty insane pretty rapidly once you hit a certain tech level, and often those units will utterly annihalate things like starbases that may have taken 50+ turns to build up in the blink of an eye.

Galactic Civilizations III is a beautiful and well made 4x space empire managment game.  Having played MOO1, MOO2, Gal Civs 1,2 and now number 3, this is by far the most engaging and challenging game yet.
________________________________________________________________
Pros:
Very nice graphics all around.  Planets now show city lights on the dark side and the background is just beautiful.  Ships also really pop out.  Huge fleet battles looks really good!
The Ship Designer is top notch as always.  Plenty of options to make almost anything you can imagin.
A lot of nice fixes to diplomacy. Every race no longer DoW for no reason... except the Drengin but that's    expected.
The absolute huge size of the galaxy makes for some epic empire vs empire wars.  I only play on Insane size!
Civilization customization is well done and there are so many options to make the civilization of your dreams.
Steam Workshop support.  Makes up for the lack of starting civs by using the faction mods and can add some awesome looking ships to your game.  Lots of great work done by the community.
Continuing the story/campiegn from previous Gal Civs.  (That opening cutscene is just AWESOME!)

____________________________________________________________

Cons:

(As of this review) No planetary invasion cutscenes or otherwise some neat way of seeing your troops conquer the planet.  It all happens in the background instantly and is very anti-climatic.  This is something that was in previous Gal Civs but not in this one and it is a little bit of a let down.  I hold out hope that Stardock will add it in either by patch or DLC.

Needs some better management/organization options for fleets.  Whenever you add a ship to a fleet it changes the fleets name to some random number with your factions name.  For me the naming of fleets is important so I can at a glance of the list tell where certain fleets are without cycling though all of them. This can get annoying when upgrading ships you will need to change the fleet name each time you add the ship back into fleet.  When I have 50+ Fleets of various sizes and purposes running around, trying to remember which ones I named what can get frustrating.

Though civilizations will not DoW as much I still have the unbelieveable occurence of some civs (Drengin mostly) DoW even if they are not even remotly in range of my empire to fight/invade.  So it is a war in name only.  The AI bu now should be able to take into account the distance of it's empire to the one it wants to DoW.  When you make another Civ know you want to destroy them they tend to prepare for you and this kind of removes the possablility of being attacked by suprise (ex: Peral Harbor style)

AI Behavior in general:  The AI can behave in some strange ways and seems to lack proper skills to manage their own planets.  I tend to find their planets near rebellion or under developed.  I then find it strange to see with such poor managment how they can afford fleets of such epic size.  In fact I would say AI behavior is the biggest flaw in this game.
_________________________________________________________

Conclusion:  Depsite the cons, which are in my opinion really kinda minor when it comes to the rest of this game,  Galactic Civilizations III is one of the very top 4x strategy games on the market at this very moment.  Very engaging and beautiful, I tip my hat to you Stardock... well done.  I look forward to see what else you bring to this game and series.

I've been playing Galactic Civilizations from the start of the series.  Fans of the earlier titles are likely to enjoy this iteration.  Most of the core ideas are well-implemented, and the look of the game is appropriately updated.  Particular highlights include a more diverse body of random events (even before obtaining the Mega Events DLC), an ideological system, race-specific tech trees, and an incredibly nuanced ship designer.  Of course, there is robust support for custom-designed content, which should proliferate as the playerbase grows.

For people unfamiliar with the series, Galactic Civilizations is about competitive empire-building.  In the standard game, a player begins with a spacefaring race still limited to its homeworld.  Simultaneously managing exploration, settlement, economic development, technological growth, and security concerns; the aim is to colonize distant worlds and thrive.  Victory conditions often include peaceful options like diplomacy or even transcending physical existence itself, though violent conquest is also on the list.  Managing large happy colonies provides the resources to attempt the loftiest goals.

Having played many games in this 4X genre, I feel Galactic Civilizations III strikes a nice balance between accessibility and complexity.  It is possible to control every detail right down to the placement of decorative fins on warships, but delegating to the AI to focus on high-level questions and strategic command is also a viable approach.  I don't yet have enough experience to have a strong opinion about the AI, but I find the normal difficulty setting suitable for learning the ropes.  Ideology is a particular treat, giving significant consequence to the morality of crucial choices.  For players willing to put in the time a serious strategy game demands, Galactic Civilizations III should provide many hours of pleasant satisfaction.

I regret buying this game. Why?
(Firstly, not one image in the videos is from actual game footage. Do not be deceived. This game relies on marketing to sell it. If you knew what I knew, you would not buy this game as it is broken in terms of functioning code and game design).

Ok, some points about my game experience:
(you can check every point in the game and they are all factual events. My opinion is not fact but it reflects my observence of these facts in the game)

1 - Crashes every 15-30 minutes on insane mode due to memory leaks. I know it's memory leaks because there are arrays being created but not deleted or reused. Too much data is being accumulated somewhere and it results in the game becoming increasingly slower and slower and finally crashing and instantly going to desktop and closes the game.

You will have a new appreciation for saving your progress between autosaves when you have long periods of time per turn before the next auto-save. Especially if you just spent 20 minutes cleaning out obsolete units to try and help the game become faster.
----------
2 - The space battles look ok at first but after a while you'll notice that it looks like all the spaceships are controlled by drunk drivers who love nothing better than to fly around like a dead goldfish in a whirlpool. This happens as they get closer and the maker seems to have a bad sense of what looks acceptable.
----------
3 - Sound often crashes. To overcome this flaw in coding: the music must be turned off and then back on - don't ask me why but it fixes the sound error. Sometimes the game will become unresponsive but not crash and return to windows. When you can no longer interact with anything, just save your current game in a new slot and re-load your game.
----------
4 - Computer AI cheats. I have it's bases totally surrounded and it magically creates armies and bases out of nothing in the middle of nowhere. Then the AI will tell me it surrenders and yet I still have to kill it anyway. Don't know if this is a bug or the game designer has a twisted idea of the word 'surrender'. Seriously, cheating is a last ditch effort for programmers who cannot make adaptive AI.
----------
5 - the game should be fun but I found it more tedious than my previous job doing data entry of government records OR data entry for Toyota.
Why would I say this? There are few shortcuts to do anything in the game. You cannot mass delete, mass rally to a location, or even mass select other than stacking and making a fleet. There are no checkboxes or CTRL+Select to make selective deletion possible.

You have to do many things individually and honestly this game felt more like a horrible job except that I'm the one paying to do it.... The hotkeys mentioned online do not work in most cases. Y" works for yes
date: the working hotkeys are visible in tooltips but the online suggestions mostly do not work.\n----------\n6 - Just when you thought you were moving a slider to look at ships in a list
recommended: the tooltip blocks most of the list so you cannot even see what you are looking at.\n----------\n7 - the icons on the minimap are single pixels. Yes
hoursPlayed: you heard correctly
voteText: single pixels!!! Get ready for purple dot units on a purple background for it's team color. THe minimap is so bad I wanted to vomit
helpfulPercent: eat my vomit
votesHelpful: poop it out
votesTotal:
eat it again and vomit it again. It will provide hours of frustration as you squint to see wtf you are looking at. Also ship icons in groupings are impossible to recognize because they are just reduced scale images of large pictures. This results in "WTF is that?" moments and you have to then open up another menu to see what is what.
And I'm using a 24" screen 1900x1200 and the minimap is still terrible. Same color for ships on same color for your area of control....so bad....high school art class FTW...
----------
8 - The production and rally points are so messy that you'll find half your army hidden in buildings that you never intended them to be in.
----------
9 - I make games for a living and so that's partly why I'm so critical. However the game does have it's promising moments but most likely you'll be forcing yourself to play because you paid 40~70 dollars depending on what country you live in. I paid 70 :(
----------
10 - The game just isn't fun at all - that's my final opinion after I completed an 'insane size map' that took me 20 hours+ (probably another 2 hours if I include the lost time due to crashes).
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:
----------
Strategy:
The only strategy really is to look at what weapons your enemy's ships have
votesFunny: what armor they have
commentsCount: and then choose the best rock

column17: scissor effect to win fights. The technology you choose should support how you want to play. Influence to steal bases

military to win fights and research to help you get an edge in whatever style you choose. Research alone will not win the game unless you choose that goal.

If you want to be creative in this game

you can make spaceships with existing parts however the spaceships update so much and the game is so repetitive AND the battle scenes are so horrible that your art will be spat on by the current game design.

Lack of patience is punished in this game.

the game's UI fails and just shows a blank screen beyond about 200 units in the list. Really helpful when the spaceship you want is at the bottom of the list and the filters don't move it to the top.

Price and Music:
Sorry to be critical but that's the way I am. I paid $70 for the game and I expected a $70 game but this seems more like a fancy prototype / alpha game. I wouldn't call it a beta because it was so buggy I really imagine the programmer to be inexperienced and not an eye for detail or design principles. Art is average but I'm very critical. Oh

Once again

reviewText:
I've played this game for a bit and I like it a lot. The ship design is cool and I've used ships from Halo and Mass Effect in games I've played, I'm using Stargate next. There are issues though, build times for ships can get ridiculous to the point it takes almost 100 turns to complete 1 ship. The more you research new weapons and such the more adanced your ships become, but also the longer they take to build.  Even with a ton of manufacturing buildings on my colony and a support station aiding in construction the build times were still ridiculous.

The diplomacy seems better than civilization but the characters have no life to them, they have no voice acting and they all use the same movements. Trading technologies can be a good way to stay ahead but if you want a ship from them you need to basically give up your empire for 1 ship. Even then it can be destroyed easily because the A.I. has no issues with construction. they can turn out fleets like they're nothing at all.

There are some game breaking bugs still, one I ran into in the campaign. I defeated the enemy and tried taking the homeworld back, but a bug prevented the game from recodnizing the ship was where it should be to win so i never did in that playthrough.

despite all of that though the game is fun, just way too long it certain areas such as ship building and has some bugs. I play this like i did Civilization 5 when it came out, all the time. Get the game and play with friends with your own designed ships, I like using the Alliance ships from Mass Effect against my buddy playing with his Star Wars ships. Its a lot of fun as long as some bugs dont bother you.

The game is a very solid game, yet the AI seems incredibly passive compared to old ones.  The AI, apparently, also knows where all the inhabitable planets are from the start since they will come and colonize them before sending scouts, even in my backyard.  While annoying, its not game breaking, but the passive AI does hinder it quite a bit.  It gives you a ton of time to slowly build up and grow before you declare war on another, and by that time, you will win most likely.
I enjoy the game but I wish it had some features that were part of GC 2 such as a list of unsettled planets, auto upgrade of assets.....
It's a game that is a lot of fun, but can be challenging.
I love this GAME!!!!!!!
Love this game it puts a great spin on other civ platforms.
Its a wonderful game.  I would like if there were more views for the space battles.  oh well can't have everything\n

Ok i put into a ton of hours into the game even more the the origianl civilizations which is a great game as well. but besides that point of the review. what do i think of the game. well considering i put almost 200 hpurs into the game that can tell you everything about it.

This game is a great space 4x strategy game. now what are thing that i like about the game.

1. your can create a custom race. I loved the customization for the game you could practilly spend hours withot even playing the game and still have a ton of fun. make what you want. I created my own rce in the game and it's awsome. and the ship designer along with factions and the workshop incorporated in the game. that can bring some more replayablility due to custom faction and make thing like x wings from star wars, or the enterprise from star trek.

2. the gameplay is solid. you have 8 races to play with their own uniqe traits and this can effect how you play and adds more time to replay value for the game. if your a fan of space/si-fi game this will be your dream game. running you very own empire the way you want and conquer the galaxy. A side note, I'd like to thank Angry Joe for streaming this game months ago, if it wasnt for that i would not be playing this game. the game is rich in content and feel just like an RPG, but in SPACE!

Now what are some thing that disappointed me or didn't like

1. No local Multiplayer but it does have online multiplayer so there that
2. There were some issues (for me at least) that the game crashed somtime while loading the designer screen where you design ship i had that happen about 2 times so it does crash and have bugs
3. the A.I. is a bit of a pushover if your playing on lower difficultys. and with that (and i can't comfirm that this happens on higher difficultys above normal) it lead to exploiting some things with the A.I. like wearing down opposing fleets that im at war with useing shipyards. So i would recommand you play on higher difficultys that is above normal. though it doesn't work all the tim but it can happen with smaller fleet sizes and having a tone of preduction to produce shipyards about every turn at will.
4. the cainpain was surpisingly short there are three campain maps though it does make up for it in time with objectives and bigger maps. at least it's not 4 hours. at least i think it is.

Now i would recommand this game but only if you like sitting at your compter for hours and have a beast machine and play for hours. if you have a low end pc it might not be the greatest thing to buy but once you get a better pc then get this game.
Buggy, I get a lot of crashes and hangs.  If you like GC then get it.  If not, wait for the price to drop.

A graphically updated version of GCiv II, with an AI that is a bit more complex.  If you were a fan before,  you will enjoy this game.  If you have never played in this sandbox, the micro-management may seem daunting, but this is the perfect empire building game that will give you a sense of accomplishment after 30 minutes, yet keep you playing for hours.  The tech tree is a little less intuitive than before, but new additions to it make this change more interesting than troublesome.  Space Battles are all about blending the right gear to best your opponent.  while land battles have been extremely streamlined, making this part of the game flow much quicker.
Lots of improvements over earlier games.  Economy/governence is much easier to understand.  I have spent countless hours playing.  Would not mind a more robust campaign mode.

This game like many other 4x games is very addictive. Its great fun and you always want to do just one more turn. The ship designer is very good and you can create just about any ship you have seen in sci-fi movies as well as design your own look. You can create and design your own race and decide what bonuses or penalties your race should have from a number of options.

There are a few things that annoy me though. Diplomacy could use a bit more work. The AI has no respect for your borders. You can't destroy their ships inside your borders without declaring war. You can't warn the AI to stay out of your borders or demand that the AI remove a star base inside your borders the AI can however request that you remove yours inside their borders.

While I really like the control you have and how much you can micro manage your empire this becomes a chore when you have say 25 or more planets. I would like to be able to make a template for the planets window where I set core buildings for an industrial planet, core buildings for a science planet, core buildings for economy planets and core buildings for a bread basket.

This is a great improvement upon an already good series. I am pleased with the graphics, design, and play of this game. My only gripe are the few glitches with battles that seem to be inconsistant. When watching a battle, sometimes the number of ships that are actually destroid is different from what the after battle screen shows. I hope a patch comes out to resolve this issue.\n\nAgain, thanks for another great game!

reviewText: 4X on an epic scale. If your machine can handle epic workshop ships too, BONUS.

GC3 is a solid step forward in 4X gaming. As of late summer 2015, the game has a few rough edges which could use polishing (sub-optimal path plotting while moving units and stale UI panel components are probably the biggest 2 for me right now). However, Stardock has released updates recently addressing other flaws, indicating this not EA style abandonmed-ware.

Most importantly:  the fundamentals foundation of GC3 appears stout. At the risk of sounding like a fan-boy, my assessment is this is currently the premier turn based strategy game on the market. This game supports the requisite feature set and strategic warfare dynamics I expect out from this genre, which the forefunner competitor's latest generation of titles should have but do not.

Kudos to Stardock for finding a working formula, sticking with it, and judiciously knowing how far to go with incremental evolution.

Best GC yet.

It looks beautiful.

It plays beautifully.

Can't recomend it enough.

After playing this game since release i am going to have to also go with the minority(but we know what we are talking about) on this and say do not buy until they add more content.  This game is just not worth the price unless half off.  Three scenarios for a game??  Come on Stardock use your brain.  I know i was expecting different campaigns for the different races or at least the major ones so to only have three campaigns for this game is a complete joke and then they will probably try to charge for them which makes it even less worth it.  There are however some pro's to this came, the ships, technology tree's, different races, planet control are all Pro's, however the major con far outweighs the pro.  Stardock if you are going to make a game then you make it in its entirety and not relase it until its ready whcih means actual campaigns.  Additionally, one of the campaigns cannot be completed at this time if you choose a certain ideology path of getting another hidden planet because it tends to spawn on a game point you need to bring down the Precursor and the dev's comment was this was unforeseen and will be fixed later.  Not a very good response.

The interface could also use some fine-tuning.\n\nI enjoy playing the game having already bought it, but until they fix this game up, I can't recommend it for others to buy.
It's an entertaining game but I can't recommend an incomplete game.  I got suckered into pre-ordering it which I regret.  Find something else.

Ultimately, a sub-par game, I mean it is playable, and has entertainment value, but it is in no way special, or masterful, adding nothing to the genre.

reviewText:
Ok, there are some negative reviews, and their issues are not wrong. On large maps the game rapidly becomes clunky and very time consuming. Micro-management of every little issue can bog turns down a bit if you are a bit of a perfectionist.

I play games to have fun however. So I just build whatever I need to keep my empire going and tweak it as I go along. That means I don't get bogged down. I would probably be thrashed in a multiplayer by an optimiser. However my turns take 5 minutes as opposed to their half hour turns and I am having more fun. ^_^

A nice big, heavily detailed turn based sci-fi strategy game with excellent race customisation, good ship construction, nicely sized tech trees and the possibility for galaxy maps that feel like they are an actual galaxy. The game does not lag too badly even on the largest maps. The automated battles run pretty well and look fantastic!

I like this game quite a bit and would recommend it. The $50 price tag is a little too high and yes, it crashes sometimes (in particular when generating a new map it will sometime CTD). The UI does take a lot of clicking back and forward when fiddling with production and taxation settings.
However if you are patient it is worth it. :)

Check it out. :D

Great Beginning! But doesn't feel finished. It doesn't have the sophistication of the interface of previous GV versions, Also, pretty buggy. Battle outcomes are changed after returning  to Galaxy Map. Game freezes with turn button. Buggier as game progresses
this game is amazing the best 4x iv ever played. its very fluid and chalanging but filled with beuty.
The designers and producers love feedback, and work hard to fix bugs. I love the large scale of the strategy of this game so much!

On the balance, I'm happy with it.
However, I miss some of the tools and options from Galciv II to automate easier.
Biggest thing I miss is being able to put a rally point on top of a starbase.

Issues:
The AI whines constantly about player military buildups. Even if you are just building constructors for mining bases. Even if you are allied with the whiner against their mortal enemy and not even replacing losses. They will yell at you for a buildup while still looking down on you for being so militarily weak.

Galactic Civilizations III is a beautiful and well made 4x space empire managment game.  Having played MOO1, MOO2, Gal Civs 1,2 and now number 3, this is by far the most engaging and challenging game yet.
________________________________________________________________
Pros:
Very nice graphics all around.  Planets now show city lights on the dark side and the background is just beautiful.  Ships also really pop out.  Huge fleet battles looks really good!
The Ship Designer is top notch as always.  Plenty of options to make almost anything you can imagin.
A lot of nice fixes to diplomacy. Every race no longer DoW for no reason... except the Drengin but that's    expected.
The absolute huge size of the galaxy makes for some epic empire vs empire wars.  I only play on Insane size!
Civilization customization is well done and there are so many options to make the civilization of your dreams.
Steam Workshop support.  Makes up for the lack of starting civs by using the faction mods and can add some awesome looking ships to your game.  Lots of great work done by the community.
Continuing the story/campiegn from previous Gal Civs.  (That opening cutscene is just AWESOME!)

____________________________________________________________

Cons:

(As of this review) No planetary invasion cutscenes or otherwise some neat way of seeing your troops conquer the planet.  It all happens in the background instantly and is very anti-climatic.  This is something that was in previous Gal Civs but not in this one and it is a little bit of a let down.  I hold out hope that Stardock will add it in either by patch or DLC.

Needs some better management/organization options for fleets.  Whenever you add a ship to a fleet it changes the fleets name to some random number with your factions name.  For me the naming of fleets is important so I can at a glance of the list tell where certain fleets are without cycling though all of them. This can get annoying when upgrading ships you will need to change the fleet name each time you add the ship back into fleet.  When I have 50+ Fleets of various sizes and purposes running around, trying to remember which ones I named what can get frustrating.

Though civilizations will not DoW as much I still have the unbelieveable occurence of some civs (Drengin mostly) DoW even if they are not even remotly in range of my empire to fight/invade.  So it is a war in name only.  The AI bu now should be able to take into account the distance of it's empire to the one it wants to DoW.  When you make another Civ know you want to destroy them they tend to prepare for you and this kind of removes the possablility of being attacked by suprise (ex: Peral Harbor style)

AI Behavior in general:  The AI can behave in some strange ways and seems to lack proper skills to manage their own planets.  I tend to find their planets near rebellion or under developed.  I then find it strange to see with such poor managment how they can afford fleets of such epic size.  In fact I would say AI behavior is the biggest flaw in this game.
_________________________________________________________

Conclusion:  Depsite the cons, which are in my opinion really kinda minor when it comes to the rest of this game,  Galactic Civilizations III is one of the very top 4x strategy games on the market at this very moment.  Very engaging and beautiful, I tip my hat to you Stardock... well done.  I look forward to see what else you bring to this game and series.

I've been playing Galactic Civilizations from the start of the series.  Fans of the earlier titles are likely to enjoy this iteration.  Most of the core ideas are well-implemented, and the look of the game is appropriately updated.  Particular highlights include a more diverse body of random events (even before obtaining the Mega Events DLC), an ideological system, race-specific tech trees, and an incredibly nuanced ship designer.  Of course, there is robust support for custom-designed content, which should proliferate as the playerbase grows.

For people unfamiliar with the series, Galactic Civilizations is about competitive empire-building.  In the standard game, a player begins with a spacefaring race still limited to its homeworld.  Simultaneously managing exploration, settlement, economic development, technological growth, and security concerns; the aim is to colonize distant worlds and thrive.  Victory conditions often include peaceful options like diplomacy or even transcending physical existence itself, though violent conquest is also on the list.  Managing large happy colonies provides the resources to attempt the loftiest goals.

Having played many games in this 4X genre, I feel Galactic Civilizations III strikes a nice balance between accessibility and complexity.  It is possible to control every detail right down to the placement of decorative fins on warships, but delegating to the AI to focus on high-level questions and strategic command is also a viable approach.  I don't yet have enough experience to have a strong opinion about the AI, but I find the normal difficulty setting suitable for learning the ropes.  Ideology is a particular treat, giving significant consequence to the morality of crucial choices.  For players willing to put in the time a serious strategy game demands, Galactic Civilizations III should provide many hours of pleasant satisfaction.

I regret buying this game. Why?
(Firstly, not one image in the videos is from actual game footage. Do not be deceived. This game relies on marketing to sell it. If you knew what I knew, you would not buy this game as it is broken in terms of functioning code and game design).

Ok, some points about my game experience:
(you can check every point in the game and they are all factual events. My opinion is not fact but it reflects my observence of these facts in the game)

1 - Crashes every 15-30 minutes on insane mode due to memory leaks. I know it's memory leaks because there are arrays being created but not deleted or reused. Too much data is being accumulated somewhere and it results in the game becoming increasingly slower and slower and finally crashing and instantly going to desktop and closes the game.

You will have a new appreciation for saving your progress between autosaves when you have long periods of time per turn before the next auto-save. Especially if you just spent 20 minutes cleaning out obsolete units to try and help the game become faster.
----------
2 - The space battles look ok at first but after a while you'll notice that it looks like all the spaceships are controlled by drunk drivers who love nothing better than to fly around like a dead goldfish in a whirlpool. This happens as they get closer and the maker seems to have a bad sense of what looks acceptable.
----------
3 - Sound often crashes. To overcome this flaw in coding: the music must be turned off and then back on - don't ask me why but it fixes the sound error. Sometimes the game will become unresponsive but not crash and return to windows. When you can no longer interact with anything, just save your current game in a new slot and re-load your game.
----------
4 - Computer AI cheats. I have it's bases totally surrounded and it magically creates armies and bases out of nothing in the middle of nowhere. Then the AI will tell me it surrenders and yet I still have to kill it anyway. Don't know if this is a bug or the game designer has a twisted idea of the word 'surrender'. Seriously, cheating is a last ditch effort for programmers who cannot make adaptive AI.
----------
5 - the game should be fun but I found it more tedious than my previous job doing data entry of government records OR data entry for Toyota.
Why would I say this? There are few shortcuts to do anything in the game. You cannot mass delete, mass rally to a location, or even mass select other than stacking and making a fleet. There are no checkboxes or CTRL+Select to make selective deletion possible.

You have to do many things individually and honestly this game felt more like a horrible job except that I'm the one paying to do it.... The hotkeys mentioned online do not work in most cases. Y" works for yes
date: the working hotkeys are visible in tooltips but the online suggestions mostly do not work.\n----------\n6 - Just when you thought you were moving a slider to look at ships in a list
recommended: the tooltip blocks most of the list so you cannot even see what you are looking at.\n----------\n7 - the icons on the minimap are single pixels. Yes
hoursPlayed: you heard correctly
voteText: single pixels!!! Get ready for purple dot units on a purple background for it's team color. THe minimap is so bad I wanted to vomit
helpfulPercent: eat my vomit
votesHelpful: poop it out
votesTotal:
eat it again and vomit it again. It will provide hours of frustration as you squint to see wtf you are looking at. Also ship icons in groupings are impossible to recognize because they are just reduced scale images of large pictures. This results in "WTF is that?" moments and you have to then open up another menu to see what is what.
And I'm using a 24" screen 1900x1200 and the minimap is still terrible. Same color for ships on same color for your area of control....so bad....high school art class FTW...
----------
8 - The production and rally points are so messy that you'll find half your army hidden in buildings that you never intended them to be in.
----------
9 - I make games for a living and so that's partly why I'm so critical. However the game does have it's promising moments but most likely you'll be forcing yourself to play because you paid 40~70 dollars depending on what country you live in. I paid 70 :(
----------
10 - The game just isn't fun at all - that's my final opinion after I completed an 'insane size map' that took me 20 hours+ (probably another 2 hours if I include the lost time due to crashes).
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:
----------
Strategy:
The only strategy really is to look at what weapons your enemy's ships have
votesFunny: what armor they have
commentsCount: and then choose the best rock

military to win fights and research to help you get an edge in whatever style you choose. Research alone will not win the game unless you choose that goal.

Creativity:
If you want to be creative in this game

Price and Music:

reviewText:
Review as of v1.4:

I am a big fan of Galciv 2 and this game hits that Galciv feeling. I have no hesitation in recommending this game to 4x players. The game is really good, no question.

The devs have made a lot of progress since release; and 1.4 is a big improvement for the ai - for me most notably is that the ai won't spam starbases everywhere anymore.

My fav things:
- tech tree is so much better than galciv2
- nebulae and other stellar background (like black holes)
- strategic resources
- ship designer - it is insanely good
- building on planets is beautiful, smooth and satisfying (especially the adjacency mechanic - making this nicely strategic)

Issues:
- still buggy in places (but have never had a full on crash). Two bugs for me are that the ai spams messages which are clearly not relevant; and some information doesn't refresh straight away creating some genuine confusion as to what is happening.
- feature light-ish (this is only a comment in relation to galciv 2, it still has a great many features). I'm sure expansions will correct this and go beyond galciv 2; as it stands in no way is galciv 3 an incomplete game.
- small payable dlc ... why are these things not in base game kinda thing

Summary:
Gameplay is unquestionably fun, the world is immersive, the sound design is great and the ai is a challenge. This is a good 4x game and I look forward to further patches, development and of course the three planned expansions.

Go buy.

EDIT: forgot to say how awesome the multiplayer is, smooth and crisp. The game is also 64 bit which is a massive step up from galciv 2 creating what I can only describe as a brilliant play experience with no lag experienced yet.

I had originally reviewed this game as recommended. I liked the soundtrack, the gameplay, and the look.  The most recent patch has overhauled" (Read: dumbed down) economic management to the point that the game is just not worth playing at all. Managing the research
recommended: and wealth of my empire and striking a balance between the three was what I really liked-the war isn't bad or a chore by any means but it's really just not where I found the meat of the gameplay to be. Now that governing my planetary budget is forcibly automated there's nothing to DO. Even the vaunted (and very fun
hoursPlayed: I might add) player-created starships have gotten hit by this change-now that you can no longer put 100% of a planet's outcome into military production all the player-made ships are too expensive to produce in any kind of reasonable timeframe.\n\nTL;DR:the meat of the gameplay was almost entirely removed in a patch
