reviewText:
Thre are definitly parts of this game I enjoy emensly but there are others that make this a struggle to play, particullarly the longer the game goes on.

My biggest complaint is the level of micormanagement that is NECCESSARY in order to play this game. There are several things in the games that *should* releive the level of micromanagement, but they don't work how you would like. There is a global production governence that allows you to drive your indistry, but having one item for your entire empire makes things difficult. if you are primarily working on research, newer planets suffer when they could be building up their infrastructure, and provide fulfilling help to the empire, but instead being on the global governence they will contribute a pitence of research and almost never build up their infristructure. prior to 1.4 each planet could have its own governence but this became a nightmare of micromanagement when you had a large number of planets. they created an interesing  in-between" that allows you to divirert things but in my opinion it is not enough to help balence things where they were before.

The game has the ability to rely on the provided ai to assist with some of the micomanagement
date: however the AI is horible. It builds things almost at random
recommended: and the ship designs are just as worse.\n\nLast complaint is the space stations. it takes roughly 35 constor modules to fully build up a space station. the AI will only create constructors with only one construcotor modules
hoursPlayed: but with some work ones with 10+ modules can be created but it requires you to specifically send them roughout the univers instead of using the "oh so conviennt" request constructor button
voteText: which only uses the base constuctor. So instead of creating 2 ships for a fully build base it requires the 35.\n\nThese are my biggest complaints. Overall though I enjoy the game as it is nice and relaxing. I just hate the 10 minutes I spend every turn directing my ships and orginizing my planets. If they can fix these things I will change my review but overall I give it an (7/10)."

reviewText:
Why did you remove the planet production wheel?

Why is it not even an option anymore?

Why did you think it was a good idea to change such a large gameplay element when it's not in alpha (or even beta for that matter) anymore?

With it's removal you've just promoted improvement spam, made the game needlessly long and made it a requirement that planets manufacture and research constantly, otherwise it's wasting raw production.

And yes I know that currently I am talking about an update that is in beta (not that it matters, major gameplay changes shouldn't be done in beta), but the developers have been talking about removing the wheel for a while. With the next mandatory update the planet production wheel will be gone.

This game has been ruined.

Edit:

The main game has been updated, the planet production wheel has been officially removed.

Edit [5/11/15]:

Despite the dev being arsey about it, the wheel is back:

1. Opt into the 1.41 Beta.
2. Run the game once.
3. In 'prefs.ini' set 'UseColonyProductionWheel' to 1.

As long as the wheel stays, my review stays positive.

reviewText:
Galactic civilizations 3 is acomplex and versatile space 4x game. It features exploration, building on planets/shipyards/starbases.
A huge tech system +100 techs. Planet manegement where you can plan/choose your funding amout into production/ research/ income.
The game features a ship designer for building space ships from the a tiny fighter, surveyer ships , carriers, colony ships, and huge starwars like star destroyers.

Galactic civ 3 also features resources, which can be mined from starbases thar are built from constructer ships.
The game has morale choices gain points in Benevolt, pragmatic or malevolt for exstra frigates, colony ship, buildings, tech  and a lot of other stuff.
biggest downside of the game is combat which is real time automated. It does look pretty
when lasers, protonmissiles and antimatter rays destroys yet another enemy ship.

The univers ranges from a few planets (tiny) to hundreds of planets (huge).
for the brave this game have max of 128 major/minor factions including space pirates.

Its worth the price if you like what it is, but its up to you if you feel like waiting.

Playing solo, 60 hrs. in, Easy difficulty.  I like the game.  Strong flexibility in initial start conditions.  8 major and a number of minor civilizations available, playable or as opponents.  Good variety of natural resouces to find and exploit, each offering quite different benifits.  Strong ability to manage economy.  Good variety of things to build.  Extensive scientific research tree.  Ability to trade / negotiate most elements with other major civilizations. Extensive spacecraft design capability.   Good use of fog of war" and sight variability.  Includes rudimentary trade / tourism that I would like to see fleshed out.  Steam Worshop connectivity.\n\nTo me
date: it seems deeper than Civilization Beyond Earth.  Similarities to Sid Meier's Civ
recommended: but doesn't feel as broad or deep to me as Civilization V Brave New World.  A lesser simulation than Paradox's Europa Universalis IV or Crusader Kings II."

reviewText: Great game.  One of the only ones of this genre that actually has a campaign.

This is amazing. If you are a fan of GC2, man oh man, you should own this. A lot of people would say that this game doesn't innovate enough, and there may be some value to their opinion. This is basically the same game, putting in a new and interesting campaign, polished up with nice graphics, with extra layers put in. Adjacency bonuses are one of the few new things in the game, a simple addition, but the fact that it makes you think about the layout of each of your planets, tickles something in me. It is a big step up from OG GC2 though, maintaining most of the innovations from the completed effort of both expansion packs. So if you go into it expecting a groundbreaking new game, you will be disappointed. But if you are a fan of the game, and can appreciate a completely rebuilt engine, polishing up what you loved for 2015. This is the game for you. *Sidenote* I invested 100$ in the elite founders pack. I know something like this is always a risk, but I am willing to bet on the company that bought us dark avatar, and twilight of the arnor. So that's it. I hope that you are enjoying the game like I am.

Great 4X game, very diversified tech tree requiring careful weighing of what you need and when. I've explored this game quite a bit and still I see myself getting back to this game in the future. Diplomacy and tech trading is important too, it's not just something you can ignore, so that's nice. Combat is simplified but the different weapon types and tech choices you have to make keep the tension on early on. Overall, I'd recommend this game without hesitation, and I should add that you don't need a total beast of a computer to play on pretty huge maps, the game remains stable and running smoothly.\n\nThe one thing that could be improved is with (micro)managing planets. It works perfectly when you have 10 planets at the start of a game, but it gets annoying once you start conquering neighbours and terraforming your planets, and it's just a total pain when you're going for a conquest victory with 100+ planets. Maybe a macromanager for planets, beyond production / science / money levels, with a build order that could be customized and applied?

This is a good game. In order to make this a helpful review I'll review different points below.


Good stuff:
------------
- The game has interesting races to choose from and in addition has excellent functions for you to make your very own custom race including; racial traits, different leader/race pictures, starting system planetary setup and so on.

- Excellent automation options. You can set rally points and many other parameters for ALL shipyards, and so on, via a very simple and fast menu, no hassle at all to manage a sprawling empire.

- Very good ship customization. This isn't something I use as I lack the patience for it, but if you like to decide how your ships should look then you can spend a LOT of time in the ship builder!

- Nice cutscenes and pictures when you colonize and gain resources. I'd like more of them though since they set the tone and atmosphere in the game.

- Not all planets are equal. Some planets will have more/less building space than others. You CAN develope them so they can house more imprevements, but only to a degree. I like this, this makes planets different and you would do well to protect your more precious planets.

- Space battles. I actually like that you have no direct control over battles. I'm the leader of the nation, not the admiral in the fleet.



- Bad stuff: (Some of this stuff is more about my own personal preferance rather than objectively negative things)
------------
- The game could have used more immersion than it currently has. Perhaps more specific and different UI:s or so.

- For me personally the mid game turns much into a click fest where I just press next turn". I suspect that this has to do with me playing too passively and too peacefully.

- I'm also not a fan of how planets are developed. Buildings of the same type give proxomity bonii to buildings of the same type. This is a true and tried mechanic but
date: without being able to give an example of a  "better" system
recommended: I would have liked a different logistics systems.\n\n- Space battles. This is my first GC game so I have no idea how battles were modelled before. But battles look a little silly. Ships bump into each other and circle/wobble around each other in a drunken fashion making the ships look like little rubber toys rather than advanced warships engaging in deadly space battles."

I've played Gal Civ 1 & 2 and have dumped over 200 hours into number 3 (get a life, right?). I've always been a fan of turn-based stratagy games and the sci fi element is one of my favorites. This game's strong points definitely shine through in its very indepth customization at the beginning which is only as complicated as you make it. Your decisions at all stages of the game have a real effect across the galaxy and after a couple play-throughs you really start to grasp the intricacies and the game really starts to bloom. There are ways to exploit (or break, depending on your viewpoint) certain game mechanics but they are easy to avoid for as much emersion as a turn-based stratagy game can offer. I plan on dumping a lot more hours into this game; very worth it.

Plus I like building spaceships and smashing them into each other.

It's a bit roughed out for AI interactions, but the AI when cranked up is unpredictable enough to leave it fun for me, plus now the multiplayer is working, I have a game that's got ~40+ hours of play with some friends and that's where all the backstabby murderlaser, you built a WHAT?, magic happens.

Enjoy folks

Its good

Galactic Civilizations 3 is certainly a good game in its current stage; however, I don't feel like it's currently worth its hefty price tag.

If you're someone who strives to stay ahead in Technology, expect an uneventful start. I didn't get pulled into a war until ~400 turns in, which means I was just improving buildings for about two hours straight. Going to war early doesn't feel worth it since it costs so many credits to upgrade your ships to the latest version. AIs seem to have a static personality for now, which means every game they'll act exactly the same way (Krynn always seem to hate me no matter what). Unlike Civilization, where you can own a single city and still manage to win on even the hardest difficulty, expanion is a must here. But, to combat this, colonizing new planets does NOT affect your overall happiness as it does in Civ.

The combat system is just beautiful. Cinematic views of battles are amazing, and feel very rewarding if you're on the winning side. Likewise, the cinematics throughout the game feel polished and rewarding; whether it's colonizing your first planet or building your first starbase, the game makes it feel like an actual accomplishment.


If you have money to blow, get this game. If not, wait for a sale. Though the game is lacking a bit right now, as most 4X games do when they're new, I trust that it will continue to expand, and eventually justify its price tag.
I'm having a great time playing this game.
Great 4x game. Better than CivBE.
4X on an epic scale. If your machine can handle epic workshop ships too, BONUS.

GC3 is a solid step forward in 4X gaming. As of late summer 2015, the game has a few rough edges which could use polishing (sub-optimal path plotting while moving units and stale UI panel components are probably the biggest 2 for me right now). However, Stardock has released updates recently addressing other flaws, indicating this not EA style abandonmed-ware.

Most importantly:  the fundamentals foundation of GC3 appears stout. At the risk of sounding like a fan-boy, my assessment is this is currently the premier turn based strategy game on the market. This game supports the requisite feature set and strategic warfare dynamics I expect out from this genre, which the forefunner competitor's latest generation of titles should have but do not.

Kudos to Stardock for finding a working formula, sticking with it, and judiciously knowing how far to go with incremental evolution.

I've played since GalCiv2, and Stardock really got it right this time.  GalCiv2 was awesome but sometimes was heavy on potential and not on delivery.   They delivered here.  The race specific tech trees, using the combat viewer to optimize ship designs, good custom race designer, etc.   It's also way less buggy than even Twilight of the Arnor was, so that is refreshing.\n\nThere are still some things (some bugginess, galaxy creator can be a bit weird, some aspects of the UI are a bit awkward, AI  can makes poor choices), but this is an amazingly deep and complete-feeling game.

First off, I'm still upset about how the Early Access pricing was handled for GalCiv3. Not cool StarDock, not cool.

That said, game's out of early access and it's decent. It's a decidedly better-than-average 4X game, and the best of the GalCiv series so far in my opinion. It's worth your money now that it sells for a sane price.

The strategic elements are pretty well polished, though I have some late game quibbles with the auto-commands. In particular, there's a critical absence of any kind of patrol command which leaves you micromanaging fleets to chase down small ships. There's also some major balance issues with sensor ships. (You can load a single ship's entire mass with sensors, park it at a star base, and have complete sensor omniscience for the rest of the game for the low, low cost of a single non-combat ship.)

The ship designer is a little awkward in spots, with controls reversing depending on camera orientation and other annoying quirks, but it allows for a lot of creativity. The workshop is full of stuff pulled from other universes, which I personally don't like, but that's sci-fi games for you. All anyone thinks to make are Star Destroyers and the Enterprise.

In a nutshell, there are better 4X games out there, but this one's not a bad one, particularly if it's on sale or if they get around to fixing balance and bugs.

Excellent game.  I highly recommend buying this game at any price; you will be well rewarded. I will list some of the more interesting pros of this game.
1.  Tech research: The game breaks the tech tree into 3 ages. In order to advance from one age to another the player has to complete a significant amount of research in all the tech trees of the current era. You might be a able to race to the end of the military related techs of the current age but you will not be able to advance to the next age in military techs until you have done about 85% of all the techs of that age.
2.  Map size:  On its largest scales I have never seen a game map with larger maps.
3.  Ship customization: This game allows you the player to make your ships as complex looking or not depending on your desire to express your creativity.  I for one like to make simple custom changes and then I just want to add components wherever they will fit.  This game will satisfy everyones desire to create complex designs.
4.  AI:  At its higher settings this game will give you a serious run for your money.

Buy this game and play it.

Opponent AI is fairly well done as is the ship design and Tech tree research functions.

Dislike the lack the a continuing research option after everything has been discovered and an overall enemy like in other galactic strategy games.

Would recommend the game however for anyone who enjoy the Master of Orion series though.

reviewText: I am a casual strategy game player and there is a definite learning curve to this game, as with most 4x games. There is a lot of help in the workshop though. If I had one complaint it would be the ship queue for stardocks. I would like a way to sort the ships by type, size, function, etc.
Could do with a little polishing but overall the best of the genre I've tried in a while.

A solid space strategy game. It has the exploration, expansion, economy, diplomacy and tech with multiple elements to a successful game. It also has a vein of humour I've appreciated.\n\nI've had the odd irritation where something doesn't work properly (seems to often be related to having a ship with unused moves at a planet/station), but not enough to break the game. Designing your own race and ships is a big plus for me. I've won games because I tweaked ship designs to exploit my own available resources and negate my opponent's strengths. Recommend.

I have all the Gc series.\n\nMinor Duvall

Played 4 games on immense galaxy - total play time approx 80 hours.   Game is an improvement over Gal Civ II

The research tree is better in that it is not laid out from the start - but you discover it.  Bigger maps = better

suggested improvements -
(1) Bring back miners on astroids as a way to increase planet production
(2) Rebalance cost of producing ships - at game start the colony ship costs 58 to 62 turns ,  quickly it becomes 300 to 500 turns which kills the game - possible solution - allow players to build older models of ship designs  the old M-1 Colony would be cheeper but slower and less range which is fine.
(3)  The special perks (items) that a few of the planets have - tool tips need to better describe their effect if any
(4) On the manage planet" screen and the Manage starbase" screen - let the small map that normally appears in the upper right that shows the whole known galaxy and the individual planet/starbase location on it appear -  location may mean different selections for actions - and on turns where I start 2 planets or 2 starbases it is difficult to know which is which
(5) Let the operator (game player) give names to rally points - the computer generated names are not helpful
(6)  Some of the color selections are difficult to see  -  insufficient contrast  -  example the yellow box in the galaxy screen that is usually in the upper right of the screen.  Yellow is a goos contrasting color but the pixel width of the lines in that screen renders it invisible
(7) In the tactical battles - give the player options of say (a) all ships shoot at enemy ship closest to them or (b) all ships shoot at most dangerious ship in weapons range or (c) ??
(8) Create a on line game instruction book - that at lease gives the basics.

Thanks for making a good game - and hope you are able to continue its evolution."

Updated this to reflect a year later.\n\nStill can't say this game is fun, enjoyable or even good.  The main problem is the terrible ai and it's lack of restrictions.  Money?  Not a problem. Ship production?  Not a problem.  Range?  not a problem. Research speed? not a problem. Fog of war?  Not a problem.  I have seen the AI chasing my ships from well outside it's sight.  I struggle to build 3 ships in the time the ai has pumped out 40. Which leads to a cycle where the all the AI will declare war on you for being to weak and then proceed to destroy your fleet and shipyards all the while refusing to make peace becasue your to weak. Oh and in order to settle any war that you have with them you have to give them a large sum of money, even if you took several planets away from them.  Oh and that tiny fleet will cost you a lot of gold to maintain, but the Ai fleets cost nothing, which will also be much more advanced then your fleet cause the Ai doesn't need to worry about research speed.. All of this was on Normal.

This game is a great space 4x strategy game. now what are thing that i like about the game.

1. your can create a custom race. I loved the customization for the game you could practilly spend hours withot even playing the game and still have a ton of fun. make what you want. I created my own rce in the game and it's awsome. and the ship designer along with factions and the workshop incorporated in the game. that can bring some more replayablility due to custom faction and make thing like x wings from star wars, or the enterprise from star trek.

2. the gameplay is solid. you have 8 races to play with their own uniqe traits and this can effect how you play and adds more time to replay value for the game. if your a fan of space/si-fi game this will be your dream game. running you very own empire the way you want and conquer the galaxy. A side note, I'd like to thank Angry Joe for streaming this game months ago, if it wasnt for that i would not be playing this game. the game is rich in content and feel just like an RPG, but in SPACE!

So i would recommand you play on higher difficultys that is above normal. though it doesn't work all the tim but it can happen with smaller fleet sizes and having a tone of preduction to produce shipyards about every turn at will.
4. the cainpain was surpisingly short there are three campain maps though it does make up for it in time with objectives and bigger maps. at least it's not 4 hours. at least i think it is.

Now i would recommand this game but only if you like sitting at your compter for hours and have a beast machine and play for hours. if you have a low end pc it might not be the greatest thing to buy but once you get a better pc then get this game.

A graphically updated version of GCiv II, with an AI that is a bit more complex.  If you were a fan before,  you will enjoy this game.  If you have never played in this sandbox, the micro-management may seem daunting, but this is the perfect empire building game that will give you a sense of accomplishment after 30 minutes, yet keep you playing for hours.  The tech tree is a little less intuitive than before, but new additions to it make this change more interesting than troublesome.  Space Battles are all about blending the right gear to best your opponent.  while land battles have been extremely streamlined, making this part of the game flow much quicker.
Lots of improvements over earlier games.  Economy/governence is much easier to understand.  I have spent countless hours playing.  Would not mind a more robust campaign mode.

It very similar to GC 2, but it is way bigger which is kind of cool.  It still has a few kinks in gameplay, but I think it's a decent game.  I really like the modding community for it now, that's really the selling feature for me.  I like being able to play as the Turians, Krogans, The Galactic Empire, etc...  very cool.
relatively fun tho I seem to have an intermittent bug that messes with the screen. Hopefully there's a patch in the works....

If youve ever enjoyed 4x games youll love this one.

The ship designer is massive and at first was so in depth as to be off-putting, but after you've played a game or two and are comfortable with the rest of the game, taking the time to custom build your own ships can be very satisfying.\n\nMy main problem with the game is that several of the tooltips need to be improved.  In particular, some of the tech's are a bit misleading if you don't read them very carefully.

If you liked Galactic Civilizations II then you will love Galactic Civilizations III.   If you love 4x turn based games,  you will love this one.   The graphics are top notch for a 4x game.  The gameplay is fun overall.  The ship battles are a bit of a snooze and there are some minor bugs the developers are working out but overall the game is the best 4x turn based strategy game out there.  The game is pretty and challenging.  It will make you think and react.  All hail the king of the 4x turn based games!\n\nWarning:  You will need a decently powered PC to play this game at full potential.   A mid class 2gb video card along with 8gb of RAM and a halfway descent processor will do the trick quite nicely.  Don't expect to throw this game on your work laptop and expect to play smoothly.

Probably the best sci-fi turn-based strategy game I have ever played.  I played GalCiv II before 3 was made and really enjoyed it, but it was getting on in years and it showed a little.  When I then heard that GalCiv III was in the works, I pre-purchased it here on Steam, and even tried out the Beta a bit.  It wasn't nearly complete at the time, so I put it down for a while.  Then I played a very similar game called Endless Space, and it reminded me of GalCiv, but was also missing a lot…and I do mean A LOT (don't play it, it'll only disapoint you).  So I came back to GalCiv III, thinking that it must certainly be finished by now, and I was not disapointed at all.  It is a simply wonderful game if you like extensively deep turn-based strategy and civilization-simulator games.  It has excellent customization ability, allowing you to truly create a civilization all your own, and design/build ships that are truly unique.  The campaign is also quite intriguing, and will captivate you if you take the time to thoroughly read the dialogues and experience the story.\n\nAfter playing again for a little while, I then went and bought all the DLC without thinking twice about it.  As I said before…not at all disapointed.  Some of the best money I've ever spent on a game.

The 3D map is nice to see but maybe too much heavy for not top-rated hardware, and there is not much video settings as well to overcome this issue, resulting in very clumsy map navigation. The campaign its really disappointing: only 3 (small) maps, too short and too easy. Kinematics clips rather poor too. As in previous version the best feature still remains the ship designer,  which on the other hand makes me wish for some more interactive 3D battles which is entirely missing. Diplomacy is somehwat improved. Commerce may be too basic.

If you were a fan of Galactic Civlizations II, you will love Galactic Civilizations III.

It seems to have everything the other game had, with all the annoying bits taken out.
Starbase management no longer feels like a chore and the alien creator is much better, allowing you to create your own races of aliens and give guidelines for their personalities.

The strong RPG element of the game is still there, with a very complex system of diplomacy. The computer opponents don't simply try to defeat you and each other; they can be assigned general personalities. The many paths to victory also allows the player much flexibility in style.

Also, I give credit to Stardock for always abiding by strong standards and providing beautiful finished products. The battle simulator is extremely fun to watch, especially with large fleets. Play is intuitive, but complex.

In short, I found it to be a beautiful, fun product that no fan of the genre will want to be without.
ground combat is poor, needs to be more like MOO3. Everything else is great.

Not without it's flaws, GalCiv3 is a an excellent 4X game that provides the depth and interest expected in such a title.  Stardock isn't done getting things right but it's definitely a playable, solid game that brings depth, choice, and fun to the genre.  It was worth it at full price but if you can get it at a discount, you are ahead of the power curve with this game.

Yeah I like the game and it's worth getting if you like this sort of genre. There are a few problems I've found personally: for a start it's sometimes dificult to see which planets are mine, making them stand out more on the map would fix it. Secondly an enemy can win, which just happened to me, and I have no idea how. It's also possible to buy ships from an ally in exchange for technology, then use their own ships to invade them. :) You can also bankrupt an enemy, as I did, by buying loads of ships from allies then gift them to an enemy, the upkeep then destroys their econimy XD.\n\nPersonally I focus on food, growth and science, I also focus on one thing at a time normally... the mechanics are more or less fine, it's really just the interface which I dislike because like I said finding things like my ships, planets and star bases can be tricky.
I love this game!!  It's not super fast paced, but the scope and scale are amazing and it's very, very easy to just jump in and play over and over.
This game is very good, but is bugged as hell .

reviewText: Absolutely awesome. I can't stop playing. The steam workshop additions are so good; made by pros. It thurned the game in a Mass Effect strategy game :)
You have to like turn based games and I wish they had more in the campaign but it's a good game.
Awsome you get to conquer enemy civilizations with ease.
4x done right.

An excellent successor to Galactic Civilizations II.  My only issue so far has been that the game will slow down to a crawl on very large maps after 500 or so turns, often taking 10 minutes or more for the AI to finish a single turn.  UPDATE: slowdown is no longer a huge issue.  It turns out that the bottleneck was my hard drive, so switching to a solid state drive sped up the game significantly.  Still no idea why there's so much disk I/O between turns, though.

I absolutely adore this series, and the third installation did not disappoint my expectations. There are countless of improvements since the last game, and everything works just perfectly. I can put days and weeks into the same round and never get tired of it. The 'One More Turn' mentality definitely applies!\n\nOne thing I personally did not fancy was how the planetary invasions have been reduced to merely being a click of a button, and Bam, you get a big Victory sign, while in the 2nd game you were treated to an actual, though rather crude, battle animation between the two forces. Just a nitpick.

Adicting
This space themed 64 bit TBS is in much better condition in Beta then many released game.
One can look at individual components ( AI, Diplomacy,  Govern game and planets, Ideology,  Ship Designer, Map, Battle Viewer or Tech Tree) but all are balanced so all components are equally needed giving the game a fun atmosphere.
Micromanagement is nothig compared to the SEV game I used to play. With all the components I still can have some things to do or change options and setup ques so I do not have to think.
The Faction editor along with all these components ensures randomness for multiple replays.
This game is also very modable so mods for the beta are already showing up.
Multi player ATM has its problems but is being worked on. I personally wanted PBEM but the AI has enough smarts so I can play with my weird schedule.
Although some do not like Steam it is needed to download and update the game. It is not needed to play as long as you can live without what Steam provides.
The Stardock name reputation and what they say makes me see many DLC and Expansions on the way to a game that will be played for a long time.
A con of this game is there is not a clock in the UI so one can easilly play to much.

They have delivered on what they said while continuing to improve the game.
Many DLC and one Expansion are already in the works.
In order to test and keep up I have played the tutorial and campaign. Both will help to understand the story and how to play the game. If one still has problems there are
https://www.youtube.com/user/MacsenGaming/videos
https://www.youtube.com/user/stardockgames
to help one see how things are done.

It has been a few month and it is calming down.
The Steam Workshop is still in its infancy but plans are there to improve it.
Along with that there are many user requests and wants that are being added over time. From what is out and said in the forums much more is comming.
By the first expansion pack this should be a decent space based TBS game.
The only downfall I can see ATM is in order to play another person you have to do multiplayer through Steam.

Update
With 1.6.1.3 out seems like the game is getting more solid.
There are still things people want but they are getting more picky. There are also some bugs that come back. To their defence they do get rid of them usually.
Multi player is not my thing so will leve that info for someone else.
If one wants to learn this from scratch they can go to Steam manuals, GC web page, youtube for Stardock and Macsen.
https://www.youtube.com/user/stardockgames
https://www.youtube.com/user/MacsenGaming/videos

reviewText: I am a casual strategy game player and there is a definite learning curve to this game, as with most 4x games. There is a lot of help in the workshop though. If I had one complaint it would be the ship queue for stardocks. I would like a way to sort the ships by type, size, function, etc.
Could do with a little polishing but overall the best of the genre I've tried in a while.

A solid space strategy game. It has the exploration, expansion, economy, diplomacy and tech with multiple elements to a successful game. It also has a vein of humour I've appreciated.\n\nI've had the odd irritation where something doesn't work properly (seems to often be related to having a ship with unused moves at a planet/station), but not enough to break the game. Designing your own race and ships is a big plus for me. I've won games because I tweaked ship designs to exploit my own available resources and negate my opponent's strengths. Recommend.
I really like this game as it is as big as you want it to be, with ship designs and strategy to choose from in so many ways.  I took a break for awhile but it is nice to come back to many times.

Great game but the built in ads for the expansion are a little annoying (showing me what I don't have when I already have steam for that) But Steam isn't their only outlet so it's not to bad. Mostly annoyed that I can't seem to register my game to get the ship building expansion/addon. for some reason it blatently refuses to accept keyboard input in the email field. Great game, but tell marketing to stop being such schmucks.

Everything is ok  excape the section where you update, or biuld a new space craft. That part of the game does not working correctly. I have designed  ships in the designs area, and tryed to save them, All it does is one of two things,one is not save the design, or save the design, but will not let you build it. The auto designs build into the program, when, you go to the next larger ship, works fine usless you want to change or upgrade systems on it. Then then it does the same thing  as I stated in line. I have all the Gc series.\n\nMinor Duvall

I've enjoyed playing but was a little disappointed it is not deeper in terms of strategy and solar systems. Planetary invasion is over simple and it's hard not to succeed in a ground invasion. Various aliens are not really very unique. Planetary defenses aren't worth putting effort into as invasions suceed anyway. Orbital spacecraft are a race attribute Paranoid" rather than technology and deliberately building planetary defenses. You can learn to put fighters on carriers but for some reason this doesn't translate into planet based fighters. Still very fun. But it could be great with a little effort. I have noticed it's alot more challenging if you disable technology trading."

REALLY GREAT GAME\nI really love this game. The story is great, gameplay is great, ship design is great. It really is a good games. Only problem is, as with all 4K games, its gets repetitive eventually. However, campaign fixes that! I really recommend this game.
beenplaying since I was on the beta. well worth the money and the years of waiting.
Only played 50 hours so far but feels like I've only just begun. Having heaps of fun, bloodshot eyes and all...
Big improvement. It's a much more cerebral game...I think.
Despite its flaws, its a amazing game. In line with all the structures of GalCiv II with serious improvements. And even with its flaws the support is responsive and keeps making the game better,

Graphics are very similar with the old one , I wanted the galaxy to look different slicker more polished, (like elite dangerous universe) The planets the stars and the background needed to look much nicer than what they look now. Great 4X game, simple enough for new players; closer to CIV V than most space 4X strategy games out there.
Fun game

For some reason this game just randomly lost the Executable File."  Now i cannot play a game i spent way too much money on! After troubleshooting this problem i had the developer realized I didnt have a 64 bit OS and that was my issue... Oh well!"

Gal Civ III is a great space 4x! Everything is so customizable that the combinations are really staggering. Its not just ship design, but race design, colony customization, the list goes on. Definitely recommend.
The game is challanging but once you figure out the mechanics it gets to be really fun with a large variety of play styles similar to Civ but with its own style and ways of doing things.
Great game

Alright.  Now, I really want to like this game.  I have tried.  I have played hours of it, but the game simply does not do it for me.  Overall, the game mechanics, the content, the tech-tree, ships, etc. on offer is plenty and varied.  However, the game, for me is too much of a reskin of GC II, which is not to say that is a bad thing, but it would seem the developers did not aim to improve upon the old game with the new.

My biggest gripe with GC III is the mundane, haphazard, and back-seated approach to combat.  There is virtually (if any at all) player interaction during combat.  The player assembles a fleet of ships, sends them against an enemy fleet and simply watches the combat unfold.  Of course, the player upgrades one's ships and develops military techology as a way to enhance the fighitng capacity and abilities, but in no way can one direct anything during combat in real time or in turn based.  This is a lost opportunity.  The devs could have really gone out and made combat interactive, and improved the old game systems with new mechanics in the new game.

A general criticism, completely shrouded in my own subjective leanings, is that the game is not immersive at all.  The music, the environment, the galaxy, the races, and so on just feels bland.  I do not get any sense that the galaxy is a living and breathing arena filled with races, wars, trade, and diplomacy.  Of course, all of these things do happen, but there is no real sense of signicance from these interactions that gives me a sense of immersion.

I would personally not recommend this game to those players wishing for a more interactive combat system.  However, the game overall offers enough content, graphical fidelity, and overall competence for me to give it a very, very lukewarm recommendation.
it's fun, but it's... klunky.  it's buggy as all hell, but if you can get it to not crash, you'll have a good time.

reviewText: I very much enjoy the obscene amount of options available for how to play the game.  The ship designer is massive and at first was so in depth as to be off-putting, but after you've played a game or two and are comfortable with the rest of the game, taking the time to custom build your own ships can be very satisfying.\n\nMy main problem with the game is that several of the tooltips need to be improved.  In particular, some of the tech's are a bit misleading if you don't read them very carefully.
hard learning curve for the tech. ai seems to be able to build large fleets quick on normal alone. fun once you get the hang of it.

I like this game and I think it's pretty good. The ship customization and starbase deployment are where it really shines, but it suffers from a lack of automation. Larger maps are fantastic but turns take a long while.

Good 4x strategy game, One of the better ones I've played. Lots oif depth. a rich tech tree, and a trmrndous amount of options for ship customization. Overall, a very enjoyable experience. Highly recommended.
Love it. It's fun, challenging, and the the customization is amazing.

Probably the best sci-fi turn-based strategy game I have ever played.  I played GalCiv II before 3 was made and really enjoyed it, but it was getting on in years and it showed a little.  When I then heard that GalCiv III was in the works, I pre-purchased it here on Steam, and even tried out the Beta a bit.  It wasn't nearly complete at the time, so I put it down for a while.  Then I played a very similar game called Endless Space, and it reminded me of GalCiv, but was also missing a lot…and I do mean A LOT (don't play it, it'll only disapoint you).  So I came back to GalCiv III, thinking that it must certainly be finished by now, and I was not disapointed at all.  It is a simply wonderful game if you like extensively deep turn-based strategy and civilization-simulator games.  It has excellent customization ability, allowing you to truly create a civilization all your own, and design/build ships that are truly unique.  The campaign is also quite intriguing, and will captivate you if you take the time to thoroughly read the dialogues and experience the story.\n\nAfter playing again for a little while, I then went and bought all the DLC without thinking twice about it.  As I said before…not at all disapointed.  Some of the best money I've ever spent on a game.

Galactic Civilizations III is a wonderful 4x space strategy game. If you like these types of game you will not be disappointed.  I have played these 4x space strategy games since masters of orion.

New elementes were added which truely improved upon this genre. Such differing tile bonus dependent on the planet, special resources which are needed for specific upgrades to your ships, the spaceship creator is amazing, and the list of improvement from the old title continue.

The epic maps that one can play now with excessive and insane is incredable. Warning dependent on your machine it may not be playable for theese huge galaxies.

The weakest part of the game is the ai which has been improved upon since release which it needed. Diplomacy is a bit weak too however as you figure out the game you will be able to make peace with stronger military powers which some complain is impossible to do. I will tell you now it is not. Even if they are at war with you it is not very difficult to make peace if you have a lot of cash on hand.

The learning curve of this type of game might be to great for someone who has never played a 4x space sandbox before but if you plug away you will find a path that works for you for Victory!

I really like the game. I really don't have anything bad to say about it except. I can have it on beginner and I can still get my butt kicked really bad.... I found a planet that had 311 Building power on Beginner.... it was pumping out ships like crazy.\n\nAll in all a good game, if you have played one of these games in the series you won't be disappointed

Thumbs up although it feels like the game is not yet completed.

There is something with the DNA of the game that makes all Galciv series addictive, but never the less this release has some issues yet to be resolved and definitely there is a lot of room for improvement. Just a few cons that come randomly in my mind:

1. The game consumes a lot of a system's resources making it “unpleasant” to run for your computer, especially if it is a couple of generations behind (Even with quad core SPU, 8Gig of memory and an GTX 550 GPU). Personal experience in first boot of the game started with a crash on desktop, not the best way for a “first contact”...
2. You just cant get some info at a simple glimpse like you did with its precursor. For example you have to hover the cursor over a selected unit to see it's movement info which is not displayed in the left bottom corner of the unit dialog box.
3. Ship types in the designer and the shipyard are sorted by default in a way that it is not helpful. An ability to sort theme out via attributes (especially by hull size) and keep things organized is not possible.
4. One should expect to see some features of previous galsiv releases be improved and new ones added. But the ones added do not make such a great impact in the game and unfortunately others have been removed or simplified (e.g politics).
5. Research, well for the standard of a game at such a level, is surprisingly poor(!) especially for one that inevitably makes comparisons with Galsiv II. It is shallow and generalized and even though the science screen in a first glimpse looks nice and developed with new features, some things are poorly designed (e.g the tech tree where you can't zoom in and out).
6. Surely the game is well polished especially with it's graphics, sound, artwork, etc... but maybe over polished on how it is presented and missing the essence.

In the other hand the AI of the game seems to be smart and quiet challenging even in normal difficulty mode. Ship designer is great and really exciting. But most of all the game has character and personality which is the timeless quality that distinguishes all galsiv series from the competition.

Summing it up; Is it worth buying it? Well, if you are a newbie in space 4X games then go for Galsiv II which even though is older, still is way ahead in the competition (and guess it will stay for a long time). However get it if you find it in a special price. If you have experience in this genre of games and you have devoted some gameplay hours in the galsiv franchise but you are sort of a hypochondriac person then don't. Just wait some time until the devs do what they have to do and improve things with future updates (which thankfully are frequent). And finally, if you are a strategy game addict and space 4X junkie (like me) than it is a must!

Update_Jan_2016

Some new updates have been released since I bought the game. The result is less sleeping, less work and more wife nagging ... so I guess that the game is on the right track !

As with all the Galactic Civ games, the Evil benefits are ridiculously overpowered. Obviously, the games developers seem to have an unusually fond love for the bad guys in their strategy games. LOL

This game is, clearly much better than the horribly messy Twilight Amour Expansion pack for Galactic Civ II. And, it does a lot to make divergent Technology Trees functional with strategy games.

However, it does not bring back any of the tortures of figuring out when or when not to switch research into Extreme Colonisation that Galactic Civilisation II Dark Avatar expansion pack did.

As with any strategy game, it is only a mathematical run through! So, don't expect it to hold any significance, other than a engaging workout to keep those binary based brain cells in good and healthy working order. LOL

Well worth buying, bit the divergent Technology Trees still remain problematic as maths problems.

Been playing this for a while now - as a turn based startegy game I think it's great. Several different ways to play, the recent event packs make it a little more interesting too. Basically, Civ 5 in space for me. sorted.

I really enjoy playing this game. I have been looking for a good 4X game and am glad I found this one. After playing for about a week, I realized how all other games have fallen short. I really like how the game gives me the option to be as detailed as possible when managing my planets or if I do not want to micro-manage, the option is there to let the AI handle it. I can see myself playing this game for hours. Bravo!
Super fun, takes a bit to understand, but once you know how to play you'll have a blast

I have been a fan of the Galactic Civilization series for a while. I recently came back to it with GC III. The game is fun but the learning curve seems to be a bit steeper than I remember. It seems like the only strategies that work now are the “Rush” strategies. I used to go science heavy. I’m sure that I’m just relearning it though. There is a lot of replay ability to this game and I still find myself having trouble not clicking “next turn”. I’m looking forward to future game balance patches but ultimately I think the game is a lot of fun.

I am great fan of GC series, so my expectations where high. Unfortunately GC3 is very unbalanced and boring comparing to GC2 and GC1. For now I'm abandoning this game for GC2Ultimate - maybe I'll give it another try after great balance patch or good expansion.
